timeline.subject: Jennon Petit Didier
timeline.details: PG des Vosges states investigation to be carried out secretly after Jennon fled when her brother Perrin and nephew Nicolas were arrested

timeline.subject: Jennon Petit Didier
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for arrest, further information, and interrogation - if she can be found

timeline.subject: Jennon Petit Didier
timeline.details: Prévôt of Remoncourt orders further search

timeline.subject: Jennon Petit Didier
timeline.details: First interrogation after she was found and identified by Curé of Haréville

timeline.subject: Jennon Petit Didier
timeline.details: Confronted with witnesses; generally denied charges

timeline.subject: Jennon Petit Didier
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture (thumbscrews, rack, tortillons); denied charges

timeline.subject: Jennon Petit Didier
timeline.details: PG des Vosges orders that she be released (renvoyée)

timeline.subject: Jennon Petit Didier
timeline.details: Released with no costs charged to her

prior_accusations.context: Father Mongin Petit Didier was executed as witch at Vitel; grandfather was also burned; sister burned at Vitel 7-8 years before trial
Brother Perrin and nephew Nicolas arrested for witchcraft just before her flight; reputation affected by association

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Petit Didier
notable_quotes.french: sur l'advis que l'on luy donna qu'on luy prendroit pour mesme crime, et la poeur qu'elle eut d'estre tourmentée puis laisser à l'abendon ung petit enfen qu'elle a
notable_quotes.english: on the advice she was given that they would take her for the same crime, and the fear she had of being tortured then to leave abandoned a little child that she has
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why she fled when her brother and nephew were arrested

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Petit Didier
notable_quotes.french: je scay bien qu'elle a eu soupçon sur moy mais je n'en peu rien
notable_quotes.english: I know well that she had suspicion about me but I can do nothing about it
notable_quotes.context: Responding to accusation about Mengeotte Rassat's illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Francois Mongeat
notable_quotes.french: mais que le monde luy en faisoit avoir l'opinion
notable_quotes.english: but that the world made him have that opinion
notable_quotes.context: Under torture, Jennon said he had not accused her but people made him think she was responsible

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeotte Vassart
notable_quotes.french: aussy qu'elle a sceu que les maulx donné de telz gens sont incurables
notable_quotes.english: also that she knew that the harms given by such people are incurable
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why medical remedies had not worked for her illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine femme Jean Collin
notable_quotes.french: et comme cest enfen estoit joieux chacun desiroit la veoir et porter
notable_quotes.english: and as this child was joyful everyone desired to see and carry her
notable_quotes.context: Describing her daughter before Jennon brought her back from church

notable_quotes.speaker: Francoise femme Claudot Gillotte
notable_quotes.french: she would not keep him long
notable_quotes.context: Threat allegedly made by Jennon about the baby, after being angry witness employed a boy to rock him

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Petit Didier
notable_quotes.french: it was nothing and she would make no scandal for him
notable_quotes.context: Calling out to Demenge Anthoine when he investigated strange noises in the night

relationships.evidence_text: Said her father had been Mongin Petit Didier of Vitel
her mother Bastiene of They-soub-Montfort. Mother had died when she was 10
after arrest of Perrin and Nicolas le Petit Didier, father and son, the father's sister Jennon had escaped
after arrest of Perrin and Nicolas le Petit Didier, father and son, the father's sister Jennon
Some 5 years earlier she had been servant in his house

relationships.person2: Francoise femme Claudot Gillotte le jeune
relationships.evidence_text: 4 years earlier had been her chambermaid
Had been in his service 11 years earlier
Previous year Jennon had served her
2 years earlier had come to her after being driven out of house of Demenge Ferry, and begged her to lodge her. Gave her a room, and they went reaping together
Asked who was father of her child, said it was Claudot Gillotte le jeune
Francoise femme Claudot Gillotte le jeune
Mengeotte Vassart de Haréville, veuve Nicolas Limosin de They
after arrest of Perrin and Nicolas le Petit Didier, father and son

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes arose from Jennon's work as servant - disputes over riksdaler payment with Mengeotte Vassart; conflicts over work quality and animal care with various employers. Her economic precarity is evident - fled leaving behind a small child, worked as servant for multiple households, had illegitimate child.

harms_catalog.harm_description: right breast and arm became very painful so she could not work; tried many remedies, doctors and surgeons without result; described as incurable
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute about value of a riksdaler received in payment during reaping
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: following year after Jennon was complaining mockingly as witness passed

harms_catalog.harm_description: leg became tremendously painful - thought he would die; recovered same day after Jennon visited

harms_catalog.method_alleged: unspecified maleficia; notably also able to cure it

economic_hardship_indicators: Jennon worked as servant in multiple households
Had to flee and beg for shelter
Had illegitimate child and was economically vulnerable
Multiple references to agricultural labor and animal care
religious_calendar_references: two successive Sundays (when Jennon was absent from employer's house)

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Kept under guard at house of Demenge Anthoine; strange noises heard in night

hearsay_chains.content: Sister made no complaint before death, so he did not know if Jennon had given her sickness
Mother-in-law took child to church with her; both told Jennon of suspicions
Other people in village said they had taken big risk by associating with Perrin
Neighbours advised her against lodging Jennon
Checked with brother's wife and found Jennon's claim about being beaten and driven out was untrue
Had heard from grandmother that mother suspected her
Told that Mengeotte had maintained until death that Jennon was cause

emotional_state_notes: Fled when brother and nephew arrested out of fear of torture
Expressed fear of being tortured and abandoning her small child
Smiled when confronted by Catherine and mother-in-law about suspicions

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Did not know cow had died; spent time at Remoncourt which broke period of service
Said she had made remark child would not live long, but it was already ill
Denied rest of story; claimed child had already been cured when she passed house
Horse was old and got stuck in harness; had not known he suspected her
Said she knew Mengeotte had suspicion but could do nothing about it; denied Mengeotte maintained this until death
During torture, said he had not accused her but that people made him have that opinion

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a particularly significant case as Jennon Petit Didier was RELEASED after torture, which is rare in the Lorraine trials. Notable features: (1) Extensive family history of witchcraft execution (father, grandfather, sister, brother and nephew all accused/executed); (2) She fled and remained hidden for months before being found; (3) She had an illegitimate child which made her economically vulnerable; (4) Multiple employer disputes and economic conflicts; (5) Withstood torture without confessing; (6) Released with no costs charged to her. The case shows the power of reputation by family association, economic precarity of single women servants, and the rare circumstance where denial under torture led to release. Key mystery: who fathered her child (claimed Claudot Gillotte le jeune, whose wife was witness #2 - adding layer of social tension). The trial lasted 113 days with months spent searching for her. Costs of 171 francs were paid at Mirecourt in December 1618, though she was not charged.
